Author: ksvs
Content: I'm not disagreeing with you, but it's interesting how willing we are to cut Google a break.  When they do something that sounds evil, we just assume it was an oversight and that they'll fix it.  Imagine our reaction if Microsoft released something with this clause in the TOS.

Author: mannylee1
Title: Anyone Need a HandCoder to do Their HTML?
Content:
I have been handcoding HTML/CSS for about a year now and would love the opportunity to help out a company while at the same time be compenstated. I am not asking for much money; just enough to get me by.

Over the past year, I have learned how to get the 99.9% of my code to render properly in IE6, IE7, Firefox 2.0, Firefox 3.0, Safari, and Opera using strict HTML and CSS without using an excessive amount of

tags. I also use VIM as my text editor and am getting faster and better at using it on a day to day basis. If anyone is interested, please email me at lazukars[at]yahoo[dot]com so we can discuss this further. I will then be happy to show you some examples sites.

Sincerely,\nRyan

Author: boucher
Content: Running SunSpider, Chrome is faster in Parallels than native Safari, but native WebKit is faster than both.

Author: boucher
Content:
Chrome is using version 525.13 of WebKit, which was just before version 3.1 of Safari, around March.

Right now Safari is on 3.1.2, and WebKit is on version 528.2.

Author: DougBTX
Content:
Gears and WebKit were designed to be reusable, other features such as the process model would be much harder to integrate into Firefox.

I'd be interested to see Firefox embedded in a "wrapper" VM, but I think you'll find it harder to implement than you expect. Please post to HN if you give it a shot.

Author: petercooper
Content: I'd buy one.

Author: rudyfink
Content:
It'll be interesting to see how plug-ins play out. Google probably does not need to provide the most feature filled browser as a core offering. Providing a simple and highly robust browser is probably more ideal. Do less but be indispensable at what you do.

I see this as a move that forces standards. Google is putting its big shoulder behind increased performance and consistency on the internet. If other people want to wrap the core offering in fancier clothes, I think Google still wins.
